Modeling collision probability for Earth-impactor 2008 TC 3.
D. Oszkiewicz1, K. Muinonen1;2, J. Virtanen2, M. Granvik3, E. Bowell4
1Department of Physics, P.O. Box 64, FI-00014 University of Helsinki, Finland.
2Finnish Geodetic Institute, P.O. Box 15, FI-02431 Masala, Finland.
3Institute for Astronomy, 2680 Woodlawn Drive, Honolulu, HI 96822, U.S.A.
4Lowell Observatory, 1400 West Mars Hill Road, Flagsta, AZ 86001, U.S.A.
Abstract
We study the evolution of the Earth collision probability of asteroid 2008 TC 3using
a short observational arc and small numbers of observations. To assess impact
probability, we use techniques that rely on the orbital-element probability density
function characterized using both Markov-chain Monte-Carlo orbital ranging and
Monte-Carlo ranging. First, we evaluate the orbital uncertainties for the object
from the night of discovery onwards and examine the collapse of the orbital-element
distributions in time. Second, we examine the sensitivity of the results to the
assumed astrometric noise. Each of the orbits obtained from the MCMC ranging
method is propagated into the future (within chosen time bounds of the expected
impact), and the collision probability is calculated as a weighted fraction of the
orbits leading to a collision from the Earth. We compare the results obtained with
both methods.
Keywords: Asteroids, dynamics, Collisional physics, Celestial mechanics, Impact
processes, Near-Earth objects, Orbit determination
1. Introduction
The near-Earth object 2008 TC 3was a small fast rotating asteroid (discovered
by R.A. Kowalski, Catalina Sky Survey), which impacted the Earth on October
7, 2008. This extraordinary object was discovered and then tracked for about
20 h before its collision. It was approaching at rather small speed of about 7 :6
km/s. Periodic light variation indicated the fast rotation of the object (period
about 1.5 min) in a complex, non-principal axis ("tumbling") state [18]. 2008 TC 3
entered the atmosphere at 02:46 UTC and exploded 37 km above northern Su-
dan. The  rst prediction (S.R. Chesley, JPL) indicated explosion and a rain of
small meteorites. As expected number of small fragments was found. A total
of about 600 fragments (10.5 kg) were collected [10]. The meteorites were later
Preprint submitted to PSS August 25, 2018arXiv:1211.3862v1  [astro-ph.EP]  16 Nov 2012
identi ed as ureilites. Collision probability computations and impact prediction
were performed at the University of Pisa (Italy) and Jet Propulsion Laboratory
(USA). Preliminary orbit computation immediately indicated collision with the
Earth, and subsequent "follow-up" observations were performed,  nally gathering
a total of 570 astrometric observations from 26 dierent observatories. NEODys
(Pisa) lists  ve other independent possible previous close approaches of 2008 TC 3
with the Earth and one with Mars. Four of which have the probability approach-
ing 100% and one approaching 50%. In Sect. 2 we describe the methods used for
computing orbits and collision probability. In Sect. 3 we present our results and
Sect. 4 contains conclusions.
2. Orbits and collision probability computation
2.1. Orbital inverse problem
An outline of the Bayesian treatment of the orbital inverse problem can be
found, for example, in [20, 13, 1, 21]. The solution to the orbital inverse problem
can be written as an a posteriori probability, using Bayes' theorem:
pp(P) =Cppr(P)p( jP) =Cppr(P)p(	(P)); (1)
where:
ppr(P) is the a priori probability density function (p.d.f.),
p(	(P)) is the observational error p.d.f. (usually being assumed Gaus-
sian), evaluated for the observed-minus-computed (O-C) residuals 	( P),

Abstract
We study the evolution of the Earth collision probability of asteroid 2008 TC 3using
a short observational arc and small numbers of observations. To assess impact
probability, we use techniques that rely on the orbital-element probability density
function characterized using both Markov-chain Monte-Carlo orbital ranging and
Monte-Carlo ranging. First, we evaluate the orbital uncertainties for the object
from the night of discovery onwards and examine the collapse of the orbital-element
distributions in time. Second, we examine the sensitivity of the results to the
assumed astrometric noise. Each of the orbits obtained from the MCMC ranging
method is propagated into the future (within chosen time bounds of the expected
impact), and the collision probability is calculated as a weighted fraction of the
orbits leading to a collision from the Earth. We compare the results obtained with
both methods.

processes, Near-Earth objects, Orbit determination

Modeling collision probability for Earth-impactor 2008 TC 3.
D. Oszkiewicz1, K. Muinonen1;2, J. Virtanen2, M. Granvik3, E. Bowell4
1Department of Physics, P.O. Box 64, FI-00014 University of Helsinki, Finland.
2Finnish Geodetic Institute, P.O. Box 15, FI-02431 Masala, Finland.
3Institute for Astronomy, 2680 Woodlawn Drive, Honolulu, HI 96822, U.S.A.
4Lowell Observatory, 1400 West Mars Hill Road, Flagsta, AZ 86001, U.S.A.
Abstract
We study the evolution of the Earth collision probability of asteroid 2008 TC 3using
a short observational arc and small numbers of observations. To assess impact
probability, we use techniques that rely on the orbital-element probability density
function characterized using both Markov-chain Monte-Carlo orbital ranging and
Monte-Carlo ranging. First, we evaluate the orbital uncertainties for the object
from the night of discovery onwards and examine the collapse of the orbital-element
distributions in time. Second, we examine the sensitivity of the results to the
assumed astrometric noise. Each of the orbits obtained from the MCMC ranging
method is propagated into the future (within chosen time bounds of the expected
impact), and the collision probability is calculated as a weighted fraction of the
orbits leading to a collision from the Earth. We compare the results obtained with
both methods.
Keywords: Asteroids, dynamics, Collisional physics, Celestial mechanics, Impact
processes, Near-Earth objects, Orbit determination
1. Introduction
The near-Earth object 2008 TC 3was a small fast rotating asteroid (discovered
by R.A. Kowalski, Catalina Sky Survey), which impacted the Earth on October
7, 2008. This extraordinary object was discovered and then tracked for about
20 h before its collision. It was approaching at rather small speed of about 7 :6
km/s. Periodic light variation indicated the fast rotation of the object (period
about 1.5 min) in a complex, non-principal axis ("tumbling") state [18]. 2008 TC 3
entered the atmosphere at 02:46 UTC and exploded 37 km above northern Su-
dan. The  rst prediction (S.R. Chesley, JPL) indicated explosion and a rain of
small meteorites. As expected number of small fragments was found. A total
of about 600 fragments (10.5 kg) were collected [10]. The meteorites were later
Preprint submitted to PSS August 25, 2018arXiv:1211.3862v1  [astro-ph.EP]  16 Nov 2012
identi ed as ureilites. Collision probability computations and impact prediction
were performed at the University of Pisa (Italy) and Jet Propulsion Laboratory
(USA). Preliminary orbit computation immediately indicated collision with the
Earth, and subsequent "follow-up" observations were performed,  nally gathering
a total of 570 astrometric observations from 26 dierent observatories. NEODys
(Pisa) lists  ve other independent possible previous close approaches of 2008 TC 3
with the Earth and one with Mars. Four of which have the probability approach-
ing 100% and one approaching 50%. In Sect. 2 we describe the methods used for
computing orbits and collision probability. In Sect. 3 we present our results and
Sect. 4 contains conclusions.
2. Orbits and collision probability computation

An outline of the Bayesian treatment of the orbital inverse problem can be
found, for example, in [20, 13, 1, 21]. The solution to the orbital inverse problem
can be written as an a posteriori probability, using Bayes' theorem:

Modeling collision probability for Earth-impactor 2008 TC 3.
D. Oszkiewicz1, K. Muinonen1;2, J. Virtanen2, M. Granvik3, E. Bowell4
1Department of Physics, P.O. Box 64, FI-00014 University of Helsinki, Finland.
2Finnish Geodetic Institute, P.O. Box 15, FI-02431 Masala, Finland.
3Institute for Astronomy, 2680 Woodlawn Drive, Honolulu, HI 96822, U.S.A.
4Lowell Observatory, 1400 West Mars Hill Road, Flagsta, AZ 86001, U.S.A.
Abstract
We study the evolution of the Earth collision probability of asteroid 2008 TC 3using
a short observational arc and small numbers of observations. To assess impact
probability, we use techniques that rely on the orbital-element probability density
function characterized using both Markov-chain Monte-Carlo orbital ranging and
Monte-Carlo ranging. First, we evaluate the orbital uncertainties for the object
from the night of discovery onwards and examine the collapse of the orbital-element
distributions in time. Second, we examine the sensitivity of the results to the
assumed astrometric noise. Each of the orbits obtained from the MCMC ranging
method is propagated into the future (within chosen time bounds of the expected
impact), and the collision probability is calculated as a weighted fraction of the
orbits leading to a collision from the Earth. We compare the results obtained with
both methods.
Keywords: Asteroids, dynamics, Collisional physics, Celestial mechanics, Impact
processes, Near-Earth objects, Orbit determination
1. Introduction
The near-Earth object 2008 TC 3was a small fast rotating asteroid (discovered
by R.A. Kowalski, Catalina Sky Survey), which impacted the Earth on October
7, 2008. This extraordinary object was discovered and then tracked for about
20 h before its collision. It was approaching at rather small speed of about 7 :6
km/s. Periodic light variation indicated the fast rotation of the object (period
about 1.5 min) in a complex, non-principal axis ("tumbling") state [18]. 2008 TC 3
entered the atmosphere at 02:46 UTC and exploded 37 km above northern Su-
dan. The  rst prediction (S.R. Chesley, JPL) indicated explosion and a rain of
small meteorites. As expected number of small fragments was found. A total
of about 600 fragments (10.5 kg) were collected [10]. The meteorites were later
Preprint submitted to PSS August 25, 2018arXiv:1211.3862v1  [astro-ph.EP]  16 Nov 2012
identi ed as ureilites. Collision probability computations and impact prediction
were performed at the University of Pisa (Italy) and Jet Propulsion Laboratory
(USA). Preliminary orbit computation immediately indicated collision with the
Earth, and subsequent "follow-up" observations were performed,  nally gathering
a total of 570 astrometric observations from 26 dierent observatories. NEODys
(Pisa) lists  ve other independent possible previous close approaches of 2008 TC 3
with the Earth and one with Mars. Four of which have the probability approach-
ing 100% and one approaching 50%. In Sect. 2 we describe the methods used for
computing orbits and collision probability. In Sect. 3 we present our results and
Sect. 4 contains conclusions.
2. Orbits and collision probability computation
2.1. Orbital inverse problem
An outline of the Bayesian treatment of the orbital inverse problem can be
found, for example, in [20, 13, 1, 21]. The solution to the orbital inverse problem
can be written as an a posteriori probability, using Bayes' theorem:

1Department of Physics, P.O. Box 64, FI-00014 University of Helsinki, Finland.

Abstract
We study the evolution of the Earth collision probability of asteroid 2008 TC 3using
a short observational arc and small numbers of observations. To assess impact
probability, we use techniques that rely on the orbital-element probability density
function characterized using both Markov-chain Monte-Carlo orbital ranging and
Monte-Carlo ranging. First, we evaluate the orbital uncertainties for the object
from the night of discovery onwards and examine the collapse of the orbital-element
distributions in time. Second, we examine the sensitivity of the results to the
assumed astrometric noise. Each of the orbits obtained from the MCMC ranging
method is propagated into the future (within chosen time bounds of the expected
impact), and the collision probability is calculated as a weighted fraction of the
orbits leading to a collision from the Earth. We compare the results obtained with
both methods.
Keywords: Asteroids, dynamics, Collisional physics, Celestial mechanics, Impact
processes, Near-Earth objects, Orbit determination
1. Introduction
The near-Earth object 2008 TC 3was a small fast rotating asteroid (discovered
by R.A. Kowalski, Catalina Sky Survey), which impacted the Earth on October
7, 2008. This extraordinary object was discovered and then tracked for about
20 h before its collision. It was approaching at rather small speed of about 7 :6
km/s. Periodic light variation indicated the fast rotation of the object (period
about 1.5 min) in a complex, non-principal axis ("tumbling") state [18]. 2008 TC 3
entered the atmosphere at 02:46 UTC and exploded 37 km above northern Su-
dan. The  rst prediction (S.R. Chesley, JPL) indicated explosion and a rain of
small meteorites. As expected number of small fragments was found. A total
of about 600 fragments (10.5 kg) were collected [10]. The meteorites were later
Preprint submitted to PSS August 25, 2018arXiv:1211.3862v1  [astro-ph.EP]  16 Nov 2012
identi ed as ureilites. Collision probability computations and impact prediction
were performed at the University of Pisa (Italy) and Jet Propulsion Laboratory
(USA). Preliminary orbit computation immediately indicated collision with the
Earth, and subsequent "follow-up" observations were performed,  nally gathering
a total of 570 astrometric observations from 26 dierent observatories. NEODys
(Pisa) lists  ve other independent possible previous close approaches of 2008 TC 3
with the Earth and one with Mars. Four of which have the probability approach-
ing 100% and one approaching 50%. In Sect. 2 we describe the methods used for
computing orbits and collision probability. In Sect. 3 we present our results and
Sect. 4 contains conclusions.

Modeling collision probability for Earth-impactor 2008 TC 3.
D. Oszkiewicz1, K. Muinonen1;2, J. Virtanen2, M. Granvik3, E. Bowell4

Abstract
We study the evolution of the Earth collision probability of asteroid 2008 TC 3using
a short observational arc and small numbers of observations. To assess impact
probability, we use techniques that rely on the orbital-element probability density
function characterized using both Markov-chain Monte-Carlo orbital ranging and
Monte-Carlo ranging. First, we evaluate the orbital uncertainties for the object
from the night of discovery onwards and examine the collapse of the orbital-element
distributions in time. Second, we examine the sensitivity of the results to the
assumed astrometric noise. Each of the orbits obtained from the MCMC ranging
method is propagated into the future (within chosen time bounds of the expected
impact), and the collision probability is calculated as a weighted fraction of the
orbits leading to a collision from the Earth. We compare the results obtained with
both methods.
Keywords: Asteroids, dynamics, Collisional physics, Celestial mechanics, Impact
processes, Near-Earth objects, Orbit determination
1. Introduction
The near-Earth object 2008 TC 3was a small fast rotating asteroid (discovered
by R.A. Kowalski, Catalina Sky Survey), which impacted the Earth on October
7, 2008. This extraordinary object was discovered and then tracked for about
20 h before its collision. It was approaching at rather small speed of about 7 :6
km/s. Periodic light variation indicated the fast rotation of the object (period
about 1.5 min) in a complex, non-principal axis ("tumbling") state [18]. 2008 TC 3
entered the atmosphere at 02:46 UTC and exploded 37 km above northern Su-
dan. The  rst prediction (S.R. Chesley, JPL) indicated explosion and a rain of
small meteorites. As expected number of small fragments was found. A total
of about 600 fragments (10.5 kg) were collected [10]. The meteorites were later
Preprint submitted to PSS August 25, 2018arXiv:1211.3862v1  [astro-ph.EP]  16 Nov 2012
identi ed as ureilites. Collision probability computations and impact prediction
were performed at the University of Pisa (Italy) and Jet Propulsion Laboratory
(USA). Preliminary orbit computation immediately indicated collision with the
Earth, and subsequent "follow-up" observations were performed,  nally gathering
a total of 570 astrometric observations from 26 dierent observatories. NEODys
(Pisa) lists  ve other independent possible previous close approaches of 2008 TC 3
with the Earth and one with Mars. Four of which have the probability approach-
ing 100% and one approaching 50%. In Sect. 2 we describe the methods used for
computing orbits and collision probability. In Sect. 3 we present our results and
Sect. 4 contains conclusions.
